texts.definition: The goal of defeating an opposing force.
markups: <style="Definition">The goal of defeating an opposing force.</style>

Games typically provide players with many goals which they need to try and succeed with. <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals are those goals where there is agents or other players that in one form or another can be perceived as a force that needs to be defeating. Typically, narration or active actions against the completion of the goals are needed for the sense of an opposing force to be present.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> uses the <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> pattern through a combination of eliminating the other player's pieces and skillful positioning of one's own pieces.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Fighting%20games">Fighting Games</link></style>, such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mortal%20Kombat%20series">Mortal Kombat series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tekken%20series">Tekken series</link></style>, are almost purely about overcoming the opponent by performing a series of successful attacks the opponent is unable to dodge or block.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person shooters</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> base their core gameplay around <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals related to other players or computer-controlled enemies.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

Central to designing <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> is deciding upon what should be <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> and how. <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> are all common targets of <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals while having <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> subgoals is an obvious solution to consider for how <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals can be completed. <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style> divides single <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals with many opponents into many <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals with fewer opponents in each while

<style="Link"><link="last-man-standing">Last Man Standing</link></style> moves the focus on <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals from personally having to be the one to <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> all targets to being the one that removes the last target. Variants for completing <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals include <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style> (e.g., <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hnefatafl">Hnefatafl</link></style>) or <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> (e.g., <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style>) - <style="Link"><link="trick-taking">Trick Taking</link></style> is a less self-evident option for games using <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style>. While often not having as clear opposing forces, <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style> shows of yet another way in how <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals can be completed (the races in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Olympic%20Decathlon">Olympic Decathlon</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Summer%20Games">Summer Games</link></style> perhaps being the clearest examples of opposing forces).

From a pure gameplay perspective, the diegetic reasons for why the <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals should be completed may not be as important as the how and what questions related to it. However, <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals can naturally arise or be created from <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style> goals as well as be an easy option for complicating <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style> goals (i.e., there are agents in the game trying to <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> those with a <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style> goal).

<style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> can be modified in several ways. The existence of <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals may make the need to complete <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals unnecessary, <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style> may make it impossible for <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals not to resolved into either successes or failures, and <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> may make otherwise allies into <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> and may also restrict how conflicts can occur compared to other agents in a game. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> can force players to have to try to complete <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals at particular instances of time during gameplay and <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> can provide ways to make <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals either much easier or make otherwise impossible ones possible.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style> goals can be seen as <style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style> to <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> since a successful <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style> is equally satisfactory to all involved parts.
<style="H3">Narration Aspects</style>

<style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> are often created to provide narrative and thematic reason to motivate the <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals to player, and exist implicitly when the <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals are <style="Link"><link="mandatory-goals">Mandatory Goals</link></style>.

Games with <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals often make use of the goals many times through the provided gameplay. Given that games often wish to have <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style>, these <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals tend to need to be more difficult as gameplay progresses which typically easily alignment with how <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> are built.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflict">Conflict</link></style> typically occurs whenever the opposing force in an <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goal has agency, and this also likely to cause <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Engrossment">Engrossment</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>. Since the opposing forces of <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals typically can oppose the goals by overcoming those with the goals, <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals typically are <style="Link"><link="symmetric-goals">Symmetric Goals</link></style> which are also <style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style> to each other. The natural thematic representation of <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals is as some form of <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> which means that this patterns typically arises from the existence of <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals. The aftermath of completed <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals can typically have consequences related to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style> (and thereby <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>) and <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style>.

Skill is often involved in some form to success with <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> goals and whenever this occurs these types of goals encourage the development of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>.

The existence of related <style="CurrentLink">Overcome</style> and <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals encourage <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> by all that have these goals.
<style="H2">Relations</style>
<style="H3">Can Instantiate</style>

<style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflict">Conflict</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Engrossment">Engrossment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="symmetric-goals">Symmetric Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style>
<style="H4">with <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style></style>
<style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Modulate</style>
<style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Be Instantiated By</style>

<style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="last-man-standing">Last Man Standing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="trick-taking">Trick Taking</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Be Modulated By</style>

<style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="mandatory-goals">Mandatory Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style>
<style="H3">Possible Closure Effects</style>
N/A
<style="H3">Potentially Conflicting With</style>
<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>
